session_1747368901222_akevotj: To what extent do you support or oppose the widespread deployment of surveillance cameras in public spaces? Please explain your reasoning.
column3: I support the deployment of surveillance cameras in public spaces if that helps reduce crime.

session_1747368901222_akevotj: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing surveillance camera coverage in urban areas?
column3: Positively, it will probably help reduce crime because it can help, you know, show what happens and you know, when you catch, you know, the bad guys. Negatively, maybe some people don't like it to be watched, but it's in public, you know, either you watch by people or watch by camera, I think it's the same.

session_1747368901222_akevotj: How do you think surveillance technologies might affect public safety and crime rates?
column3: The surveilling technologies can help make it safer, make it safer for the area, for the local, and try to, you know, solve crime, solve crime, you know, better, faster.

session_1747368901222_akevotj: What impact do you believe increased surveillance might have on personal privacy and individual liberties?
column3: It's not really a lot, really in the public, you know, like I said, either watched by some other people or you'll be watched by the camera. So it's not that much difference, unless you're doing something bad, you know, and on the other way that if we get a safer, better, you know, community, I think it's worth it.

session_1747368901222_akevotj: How do you think surveillance camera systems might affect community trust and police-community relations?
column3: I think it will increase trust, community trust, because, you know, we are all part of it. If we were thinking like, oh, it's me, you know, I don't want this, I don't want that. We are part of the community, the community should work together, and this is for public safe. We are one whole, one.

column3: I think we should have the government to train some people, just like police, like police patrol around the area, but you have some police patrol, you know, using, viewing the camera data.

So when we've more, just more evidence to consider, we're provided by this surveillance camera data, and it could be a good thing.

So they are aware of it and I think it's just communication and once people get used to it, it shouldn't be a big deal because it's already, you know, the parts are put in effect in London I think and so far so good, no big deal and I think it helped.
